instruction.display:
In this activity, you will use a model
of air particles to investigate how
they behave.

airChamber.label: Air chamber
airChamber.description: An air chamber is a container with very strong walls. It is sealed, so no air can get in or out unless we pump it in (or out).

question.title: Question 1
question.question: What happens when air particles collide with each other?

correct.display:
Well done!

The particles bounce off each other and continue in a new direction.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Have another look at the model.

Still not correct.

Follow the path of one air particle in the chamber. Watch what happens to it when it hits another particle.

No, that's still not right.

The particles change direction.

question.title: Question 2
question.question: Look closely at the direction of the particles after they collide with the wall. How do they move?

options.option: They move back along the same track as before the collision.
They move at the same angle to the wall, but in a different direction.
They move at right angles to the wall.

correct.display:
Well done!

The particles bounce off at the same angle, they 'reflect'. The force of all the air particles hitting the walls
of the container is what causes
'air pressure'.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Have another look at the model.

Still not correct.

Follow the path of one particle. Watch what happens to it when it hits the wall of the chamber.

No, that's still not right.

The particles bounce off at the same angle, they 'reflect'. The force of all the air particles hitting the walls of
the container is what causes
'air pressure'.

question.title: Question 3
question.question:
In this model of an air chamber, what do you think is between
the particles?

correct.display:
Well done!

There is just empty space between the particles in a gas.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Have another look at the model.

Still not correct.

The model shows all the particles that are in the chamber.

No, that's still not right.

There is nothing between the air particles.

question.title: Question 4
question.question:
The tiny air particles move around the whole space of the container, like all gas particles. Imagine the same particles stopped moving and were all packed closely together.

How much of the volume of the container would they take up?

correct.display:
Well done!

The total volume of the particles is very small compared to the space they take up when moving around
as a gas.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Imagine these same particles are packed closely together.

Still not correct.

Look at the amount of space between the particles.

No, that's still not right.

The particles would take up hardly any of the space. Their total volume is very small compared to the space they take up when moving around as a gas.

question.title: Question 5
question.question:
Turn up the heat and raise the temperature in the chamber.
Watch the air particles.

How do they move?

options.option: They continue to move in the same way.

correct.display:
Well done!

The air particles move faster at
higher temperatures because
they gain energy.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Change the temperature of the
air chamber.

Still not correct.

Use the heating controls to raise
the temperature and watch the
air particles.

No, that's still not right.

The air particles move faster at
higher temperatures because
they gain energy.

question.title: Question 6
question.question: Turn up the heat again and this time, watch the pressure gauge. What happens to air pressure in the chamber as the temperature rises?

correct.display:
Well done!

The air particles move faster at
higher temperatures and the
air pressure increases.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Change the temperature of the
air chamber.

Still not correct.

Use the heating controls to raise
the temperature and watch the
pressure gauge.

No, that's still not right.

The air particles move faster at
higher temperatures and the
air pressure increases.

question.title: Question 7
question.question:
Now cool down the air in the chamber and watch the air particles.

How do they move?

options.option: They continue to move in the same way.

correct.display:
Well done!

The air particles move slower at
lower temperatures because they
lose energy.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Change the temperature of the
air chamber.

Still not correct.

Use the temperature controls to
cool the chamber and watch the
air particles.

No, that's still not right.

The air particles move slower at
lower temperatures because they
lose energy.

question.title: Question 8
question.question:
Turn down the heat again and this time, watch the pressure gauge. What happens to air pressure in
the chamber as the temperature decreases?

correct.display:
Well done!

The air particles move slower at lower temperatures and the air pressure decreases.

incorrect.display:
That's not correct.

Change the temperature of the
air chamber.

Still not correct.

Use the heating controls to cool the chamber and watch the pressure gauge.

No, that's still not right.

The air particles move slower at lower temperatures and the air pressure decreases.

outro_aggregate.display:
Good work!

Now you know a lot about how
air particles behave. They are very
tiny, and as a gas they move fast
and have lots of empty space
between them.

Air pressure comes from the force
of all the air particles hitting the
walls of the container. When the
temperature rises, the particles
gain energy and move faster.
This makes the collisions harder
and air pressure higher.
